bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry A. Christian, June 18, 1948

div1.p: Hench sends Christian a copy of the Hall of Fame program and informs him that the Cuban government has set aside funds to memorialize Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Henry A. Christian, June 18, 1948
div1.opener:
desk
June 18, 1948
Dr. Henry A. Christian
20 Chapel Street
Brookline 46, Massachusetts
My dear Doctor Christian:
div1.p:
Thank you very much indeed for your courteous note regarding my little
paper on Walter Reed and the Conquest of Yellow Fever. I gave this talk
(illustrated) at the University of Virginia. They asked for a manuscript ahead
of time for their college publicity and I didn't realize it was being published
until I received the proof from Pharos. I had to make a few quick, minor cor-
rections.

You may be interested to know that I made another trip to Cuba on my
spring vacation and was finally successful in having the Cuban Government set
aside a preliminary sum of $50,000 to memorialize Camp Lazear and the remains
of Reed's Building Number One which they are going to enclose in a memorial
building with suitable tablets, busts, etc., and also a great amount of souvenir
data which I and others have collected. The whole adventure has been a very
pleasant affair although at times quite exasperating because of the Cuban's
characteristic of manana. Through this adventure I have gotten to know quite
intimately the Reed family, General Ireland, General and Mrs. Kean and the
Lazear family

I gave an abstract of this talk at the International Congress on
Tropical Medicine a month ago in Washington and the following week went to New
York for the unveiling of the Reed statue in the Hall of Fame. They published
a very interesting little program, a copy of which I enclose. You may keep it
if you wish.

It must have been indeed a pleasure for you to have known these men
so intimately. I, of course, never met any of the four charter members, only the
surviving relatives. Did you know that Mrs. Walter Reed is still living, or I
should say existing, at the age of 90 something? I have seen her every now and
then at her home at Blue Ridge Summit, Pennsylvania.

I am glad to have your comments suggesting that Reed's accomplishment
in graduating from the Medical School of the University of Virginia in one year
was not as outstanding as some would have you believe. I suspected that was the
case but naturally have never tried to belittle his accomplishment unduly, cer-
tainly not at the University of Virginia where Reed is of course one of their
favorite sons (my brother has been professor of English Literature there for many
years). Again, let me thank you for your interest and comments in this little talk.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
